Comment: > I think it’s just an extra tax to use the road  Yes, that is the entire point. One of the levers of power governments can use to influence behavior is a tax. In this case, New York was able to [decrease travel times between 10% on the low end at the Manhattan Bridge to 65% at the Holland Tunnell](https://lede-admin.nyc.streetsblog.org/wp-content/uploads/sites/48/2025/01/congestion-pricing-week-one-bridges-tunnels-1.jpg?w=710&quality=75) ([data pulled from here](https://data.ny.gov/Transportation/MTA-Bridges-Tunnels-Hourly-Traffic-Rates-2010-2025/qzve-kjga/about_data))  They removed 7.5% of cars from the roadways in the business district, decreased travel times significantly, funded public transit, reduced motor vehicle collisions, etc.  Sometimes there are other reasons to use a "stick" in policy besides just maintenance for the roadway. Especially when most of the users that are causing the wear and tear on the roadways don't actually live in or pay taxes to the jurisdiction that collects them to maintain the roads.
